bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. FORTENBERRY:H.R. 5935.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:The constitutional authority for this bill is pursuant toArticle I, Section 8, Clause 18 of the United StatesConstitution.[Page H3699]

item.name: Energy, Climate and Grid Security Subcommittee

item.title: A bill to prohibit the Secretary of Energy from enforcing regulations pertaining to certain battery chargers.

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources.

item.name: Energy, Climate and Grid Security Subcommittee

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Energy and Power.
Referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce.

summary.text: Prohibits the Secretary of Energy from finalizing, implementing, or enforcing a proposed rule entitled "Energy Conservation Program: Energy Conservation Standards for Battery Chargers and External Power Supplies," or any substantially similar regulation, regarding product class 7 (certain high-energy battery chargers described in such proposed rule).

bill.title: To prohibit the Secretary of Energy from enforcing regulations pertaining to certain battery chargers.

item.title: To prohibit the Secretary of Energy from enforcing regulations pertaining to certain battery chargers.
To prohibit the Secretary of Energy from enforcing regulations pertaining to certain battery chargers.

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Energy and Power.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
